summary: This document is a series of U.S. Marshals Service investigation reports concerning Jeffrey Epstein's compliance with sex offender travel reporting requirements under International Megan's Law. It details witness interviews, investigative steps, and the closure of the case following Epstein's death. The reports include allegations of Epstein traveling with young girls and failing to report international destinations.

persons.name: Jeffrey Edward Epstein
persons.role: Convicted sex offender, subject of investigation
persons.context: The primary subject of the U.S. Marshals Service investigation for potential violations of International Megan's Law due to unreported international travel. He is described as a convicted sex offender who traveled frequently on a private jet (N212JE).

persons.name: Senior Inspector (SI)
persons.context: The primary investigator conducting witness interviews, coordinating with the AUSA's office, and submitting search warrants and MLAT requests related to Epstein's travel.

persons.name: Supervisory Inspector (SI)
persons.context: Met with a Miami Herald reporter to gather information and potential informants related to Epstein's activities.

persons.name: AUSA
persons.context: The prosecutor's office in the U.S. Virgin Islands that the Senior Inspector coordinated with to submit MLAT requests and discuss the case. Agreed to drop the case after Epstein's death.

persons.name: Miami Herald Reporter
persons.context: Met with Marshals investigators and provided information about potential informants, including an airport worker who saw Epstein with young girls and a disgruntled former attorney of Epstein's.

connections.description: The Senior Inspector was the lead investigator for the U.S. Marshals Service probing Epstein's potential failure to report international travel as required by law.
The reporter was investigating Epstein and provided law enforcement with leads from informants regarding his activities with young girls.
The AUSA's office worked with the Senior Inspector to submit legal requests (MLATs, search warrants) and ultimately decided to close the case after Epstein's death.

events.title: Epstein's Florida Conviction
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was convicted in Florida of procuring a person under the age of 18 for prostitution and sentenced to 13 months incarceration, requiring him to register as a sex offender.

events.title: Epstein Reports Travel in USVI
events.description: Epstein visited the US Virgin Islands Department of Justice on St. Thomas and signed a Notification of Duty to Report travel with the Sex Offender Registry Coordinator.

events.title: Reported Travel to France
events.description: Epstein notified authorities of travel to France via his private jet (N212JE). However, flight tracking showed additional, unreported travel to Vienna, Austria and Monaco.

events.title: Interview with Miami Herald Reporter
events.description: U.S. Marshals Supervisory and Senior Inspectors met with a Miami Herald reporter at a diner in Hollywood, Florida. The reporter provided leads about informants who had witnessed Epstein with young girls.

events.title: Witness Interview with Air Traffic Controller
events.description: A Senior Inspector interviewed a female air traffic controller by phone. She stated she had seen Epstein disembark his plane at the airport with young girls, some appearing as young as 11-12 years old, between June/July and November 2018.

events.title: Epstein's Suicide
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein committed suicide while in custody in New York.

events.title: Case Closure Decision
events.description: Following Epstein's death, the Senior Inspector spoke with the US Virgin Islands AUSA's office, and all parties agreed to drop the case, canceling all pending search warrants, MLAT requests, and investigative activities.

locations: U.S. Virgin Islands (specifically St. Thomas and Little St. James island)
Morocco (mentioned as a country for a planned MLAT request)
keyFacts: A U.S. Marshals Service investigation was actively pursuing Jeffrey Epstein in 2019 for potential violations of International Megan's Law related to his failure to report all international travel as a registered sex offender.
An air traffic controller witness reported observing Epstein get off his private plane at an airport with young girls, some appearing to be as young as 11-12 years old, on multiple occasions in 2018.

Flight tracking data revealed Epstein traveled to Vienna, Austria and Monaco in March 2019, destinations he did not list on his official sex offender travel notification form which only listed France.
The investigation was abruptly closed and all pending investigative actions (search warrants, international MLAT requests) were canceled following Epstein's suicide on August 10, 2019.
A Miami Herald reporter provided investigators with leads, including information about a disgruntled former Epstein attorney and a former police chief involved in the original Epstein investigation.
